Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “We’re all about quality jobs, and that’s a quality organization,” Bob Durkin, the president and chief executive officer of the Scranton Chamber of Commerce said. “So the infusion of additional funding to support is important to us.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: President and Chief Executive Officer of the Scranton Chamber of Commerce
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Bob Durkin, the president and chief executive officer of the Scranton Chamber of Commerce

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “It’s not $277 million that stays here. But, you know, it’s a good chunk of it,” Cartwright said. “And it’s important that we keep that work coming.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Congressman Matt Cartwright, who sits on the House Appropriations Committee and represents Scranton and other parts of Northeastern Pennsylvania

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “I don’t really think that people dwell or concentrate on anything that’s going on outside of their sphere of influence,” Rich Hansen, the Commander’s Representative at the Scranton Army Ammunition Plant, said. we’re kind of busy concentrating on what’s going on in Scranton.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Commander’s Representative at the Scranton Army Ammunition Plant
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Rich Hansen, the Commander’s Representative at the Scranton Army Ammunition Plant

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “We had a job fair in the middle of a heat wave and there was still a line going out of the door,” Danielle Weinschenk, the lead Public Affairs Specialist at the Tobyhanna Army Depot said. “We had another one when it was pouring rain, and the same thing happened.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Lead Public Affairs Specialist at the Tobyhanna Army Depot
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Danielle Weinschenk, the lead Public Affairs Specialist at the Tobyhanna Army Depot

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “With the Ukraine support, you know, one day I was sitting there thinking about what needs to be done, and it kind of hit me that what we were doing directly affects whether people live or die,” said Jim Jarick, a senior technology center engineer at the Tobyhanna Army Depot. “If we aren’t doing our job correctly, people could die tomorrow. And that just put this whole thing in perspective for me.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Senior Technology Center Engineer at the Tobyhanna Army Depot
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Jim Jarick, a senior technology center engineer at the Tobyhanna Army Depot

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “At the height of last year’s counteroffensive, the Ukrainians were firing about 6,000 a day, ” Cancian said. “The Russians are [firing] probably about 10,000 a day.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Senior Advisor at the Center for Strategic and International Studies
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Mark Cancian, a senior advisor at the Center for Strategic and International Studies

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Our first task is to save our people,” Popov said. “Without artillery, we cannot do this.”
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Commander of a Ukrainian artillery unit
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Col. Olksandr Popov, the commander of a Ukrainian artillery unit

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: The U.S. Army was making 14,000 artillery shells a month prior to the conflict. Now, officials at the plant told Morning Edition that the army is producing 36,000 shells a month, up from 24,000 just six months ago.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: Officials at the plant told Morning Edition

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: The Tobyhanna Army Depot, which specializes in logistics support and radar equipment for foreign allies such as Ukraine, estimates that the company has a $2.4 billion dollar impact on the area and that it is the largest industrial employer in the region.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: The Tobyhanna Army Depot, which specializes in logistics support and radar equipment for foreign allies such as Ukraine

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: Officials at Tobyhanna estimate that its average annual salary is $30,000 higher than the average salary in northeastern Pennsylvania, which is around $58,000 in 2021.
